questions.question_content:
1. To gain some familiarity with sets and operations on them, prove the following relations algebraically, and where possible draw the corresponding Venn diagrams.
(a) $A \cup \emptyset=A$
(b) $A \cap \emptyset=\emptyset$
(c) $A \cup B=B \cup A$
(d) $A \cap B=B \cap A$
(e) $A \subseteq A \cup B$
(f) $A \cup(B \cap A)=A$
(g) $A \cap(B \cup A)=A$
(h) $(A \backslash C) \cap(B \backslash C)=(A \cap B) \backslash C$
(i) $(A \cap B)^{\prime}=A^{\prime} \cup B^{\prime}$
questions.solution_content:
1. (a) $A \cup \phi=A$  
(i) $x \in A \cup \phi \Rightarrow x \in A$ or $x \in \varnothing$ so $x \in A$ $\Rightarrow A \cup \Phi \subseteq A$.  
(ii) $x \in A \Rightarrow x \in A$ or $x \in \phi$ (although $x \notin \phi$ ) $\Rightarrow x \in A \cup \varnothing$ so $A \subseteq A \cup \phi$ hence $A=A \cup \phi$.  
(b) $A \cap \phi=\phi$.  
LHS means $x \in A$ and $x \in \phi$, but that are no $x \in \varnothing$ so the statement is vacuous and therefore $A \cap \varnothing=\varnothing$.  
(c) $A \cup B=\{x \mid x \in A$ or $x \in B\}$  
$$
=\{x \mid x \in B \text { or } x \in A\}=B \cup A
$$
(d) $A \cap B=\{x \mid x \in A$ and $x \in B\}=B \cap A$.  
(e) $A \subseteq A \cup B$ $x \in A \Rightarrow x \in A$ or $B$, ie $x \in A \cup B$ $\Rightarrow A \subseteq A \cup B$.  
(f) $A \cup(B \cap A)=A$ $x \in A \cup(B \cap A)$ means $x \in A$ or $x \in(B \cap A)$ $x \in B$ and $x \in A$.  
(g) $A \cap(B \cup A)=A$ $x \in A \cap(B \cup A)$ means $x \in A$ and $(x \in B$ or $x \in A)$.  
(h) $(A \backslash C) \cap(B \backslash C)=(A \cap B) \backslash C$ $x \in(A \backslash C) \cap(B \backslash C)$ $\Rightarrow x \in(A \backslash C)$ and $x \in(B \backslash C)\Rightarrow x \in A, x \notin C$ and $x \in B, x \notin C\Rightarrow x \in A$ and $x \in B$ and $x \notin C\Rightarrow x \in A \cap B, x \notin C\Rightarrow x \in A \cap B \backslash C$.  
(i) $(A \cap B)^{\prime}=A^{\prime} \cup B^{\prime}$ $x^{\notin(A \text { and } B)}$.  
$$
\begin{aligned}
(A \cap B)^{\prime}= & \{x \mid x \notin(A \cap B)\} \\
& \Rightarrow x \notin A \text { or } x \notin B \\
& \Rightarrow x \in A^{\prime} \text { or } x \in B^{\prime} \\
& =A^{\prime} \cup B^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$
2. (a) $A \cap B=\{1,2,3\} \cap\{1,2\}=\{1,2\}=B$.  
(b) $A \cup B=\{1,2,3\} \cup\{1,2\}=\{1,2,3\}=A$.  
(c) $A \cap(B \cap C)=A \cap\{1\}=\{1\}=E$.  
(d) $(C \cup A) \cap B=A \cap B=B$.  
(e) $A \backslash B=\{3\}=G$.  
(f) $C \backslash A=\phi=H$.  
(g) $(D \backslash F) \cup(F \backslash D)=\{3\} \cup \phi=\{3\}=G$.  
(h) $G \backslash A=\phi=H$.  
(i) $A \cup((B \backslash C) \backslash F)=A \cup(\{2\} \backslash F)\Rightarrow A \cup \phi=A=\text{(k) } H \cup H=H$.  
3. $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots x_{n+1}$  
Let $\frac{x_{1}}{n}=p_{1}+F_{1} \cdot \frac{x_{i}}{n}=p_{i}+F_{i}$ etc. $i=1, n+1$.  
$p_{i} \in \mathbb{N}, F_{i}$ is the fractional remainders and clearly $F_{i}$ takes one of the values $F_{c}=0 / n, 1 / n, \cdots \text { or } n-1 / n$  
Hence there are $n$ usable distinct values for $(n+1) F_{i} \Rightarrow 2$ of the $F_{i}$ must be equal, $F^{\prime}$ and $F^{\prime \prime}$ say.  
4. Let $f: A \rightarrow B, g: B \rightarrow C$.  
(a) If $f, g$ are surjective. If $c \in C$, then $\exists \quad b \in B$ such that $g(b)=c$. Also $f$ is surjective so $\exists a \in A$ such that $f(a)=b$.  
So $(g \circ f)(a)=g(f(a))=g(b)=c$ hence $g \circ f$ is SURJECTIVE.  
(b) If $f, g$ are injective. $a, a^{\prime} \in A$ and $y \quad a \neq a^{\prime}$, then $f(a) \neq f(a^{\prime})$, since $f$ injective. Since $g$ is also injective, $g(f(a)) \neq g(f(a^{\prime}))$, so $g \circ f$ is injective.  
5. (i)  
$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=(f \circ g)^{-1}(x) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & x =(f \circ g)(y) \\
& =f(g(y)) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & f^{-1}(x)=g(y) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & g^{-1}(f^{-1}(x))=y
\end{aligned}
$$
Comparing (1) and (2) $\Rightarrow (f \circ g)^{-1}=g^{-1} \circ f^{-1}$.  
(ii) $(f \circ(g \circ h))(x)$  
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =f((g \circ h)(x)) \\
& =f(g(h(x)) \\
& =(f \circ g)(h(x)) \\
& =((f \circ g) \circ h)(x)
\end{aligned}
$$
so $f \circ(g \circ h)=(f \circ g) \circ h$.

questions.question_content:
2. Let $A=\{1,2,3\}, B=\{1,2\}, C=\{1,3\}, D=\{2,3\}, E=\{1\}, F=\{2\}, G=\{3\}$, $H=\emptyset$. Simplify the following expressions. In each case the answer should be one of the sets $A, B \cdots H$.
(a) $A \cap B$
(b) $A \cup B$
(c) $A \cap(B \cap C)$
(d) $(C \cup A) \cap B$
(e) $A \backslash B$
(f) $C \backslash A$
(g) $(D \backslash F) \cup(F \backslash D)$
(h) $G \backslash A$
(i) $A \cup((B \backslash C) \backslash F)$
(j) $H \cup H$
(k) $A \cap A$
(l) $((B \cup C) \cap C) \cup H$
questions.solution_content:
2. (a) $A \cap B=\{1,2,3\} \cap\{1,2\}=\{1,2\}=B$.  
(b) $A \cup B=\{1,2,3\} \cup\{1,2\}=\{1,2,3\}=A$.  
(c) $A \cap(B \cap C)=A \cap\{1\}=\{1\}=E$.  
(d) $(C \cup A) \cap B=A \cap B=B$.  
(e) $A \backslash B=\{3\}=G$.  
(f) $C \backslash A=\phi=H$.  
(g) $(D \backslash F) \cup(F \backslash D)=\{3\} \cup \phi=\{3\}=G$.  
(h) $G \backslash A=\phi=H$.  
(i) $A \cup((B \backslash C) \backslash F)=A \cup(\{2\} \backslash F)=A \cup\phi=A=\text{(k) } H \cup H=H$.

questions.question_content: 3. Use the pigeonhole principle to prove that in any set of $n+1$ integers, there must be two integers whose difference is divisible by $n$.
questions.solution_content:
3. $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots x_{n+1}$  
Let $\frac{x_{1}}{n}=p_{1}+F_{1} \cdot \frac{x_{i}}{n}=p_{i}+F_{i}$ etc. $i=1, n+1$.  
$p_{i} \in \mathbb{N}, F_{i}$ is the fractional remainders and clearly $F_{i}$ takes one of the values $F_{c}=0 / n, 1 / n, \cdots \text { or } n-1 / n$  
Hence there are $n$ usable distinct values for $(n+1) F_{i} \Rightarrow 2$ of the $F_{i}$ must be equal, $F^{\prime}$ and $F^{\prime \prime}$ say.

questions.question_content: 4. Show that the composition of two injective maps is injective, and the composition of two surjective maps is surjective. Deduce that the composition of two bijective maps is bijective.
questions.solution_content:
4. Let $f: A \rightarrow B, g: B \rightarrow C$.  
(a) If $f, g$ are surjective. If $c \in C$, then $\exists \quad b \in B$ such that $g(b)=c$. Also $f$ is surjective so $\exists a \in A$ such that $f(a)=b$.  
So $(g \circ f)(a)=g(f(a))=g(b)=c$ hence $g \circ f$ is SURJECTIVE.  
(b) If $f, g$ are injective. $a, a^{\prime} \in A$ and $y \quad a \neq a^{\prime}$, then $f(a) \neq f(a^{\prime})$, since $f$ injective. Since $g$ is also injective, $g(f(a)) \neq g(f(a^{\prime}))$, so $g \circ f$ is injective.

questions.question_content:
5. In the following question you may assume that the domains and codomains of the functions $f, g, h$ are suitably defined and that inverses exist. Show that
(i) $(f \circ g)^{-1}=g^{-1} \circ f^{-1}$
(ii) $f \circ(g \circ h)=(f \circ g) \circ h$
questions.solution_content:
5. (i)  
$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=(f \circ g)^{-1}(x) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & x =(f \circ g)(y) \\
& =f(g(y)) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & f^{-1}(x)=g(y) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & g^{-1}(f^{-1}(x))=y
\end{aligned}
$$
Comparing (1) and (2) $\Rightarrow (f \circ g)^{-1}=g^{-1} \circ f^{-1}$.  
(ii) $(f \circ(g \circ h))(x)$  
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =f((g \circ h)(x)) \\
& =f(g(h(x)) \\
& =(f \circ g)(h(x)) \\
& =((f \circ g) \circ h)(x)
\end{aligned}
$$
so $f \circ(g \circ h)=(f \circ g) \circ h$.
